items.title: Incorrect results using PuLP 2.3
items.body:
Python version 3.7.7

PuLP  2.3 is achieving incorrect results on simple problems.

Here is a link to a problem and its correct simplex solution: http://simplex.tode.cz/en/wql6czm8gz1

Here is the formulation and solution obtained when using PuLP to solve this same problem:

input:
```
prob2 = p.LpProblem('ex_b', p.LpMaximize)

x1 = p.LpVariable("x1", lowBound = 0) 
x2 = p.LpVariable("x2", lowBound = 0) 
x3 = p.LpVariable("x3", lowBound = 0) 

prob2 += 1*x1 - 2*x2 + 1*x3   
  
# Constraints: 
prob2 += 1*x1 + 1*x2 + 1*x3 <= 12
prob2 += 2*x1 + 1*x2 - 1*x3 <= 6
prob2 += -1*x1 + 3*x2  <= 9

status = prob2.solve()
print(p.LpStatus[status])
for var in (x1,x2,x3):
    print('Optimal number of {} to produce is: {:1.0f}'
          .format(var.name, var.value()))
print('Optimal value: ', p.value(prob2.objective))
```

output:
```
Optimal
Optimal number of x1 is: 0
Optimal number of x2 is: 0
Optimal number of x3 is: 12
Optimal value:  12.0
```

items.title: Fix makeDict incorrectly generating defaultdict
items.body:
Hi, everyone. I'm learning optimization with PuLP and was trying to have a better understanding on how `makeDict()` behaves. Looking at the current code on `utilities.py`, I noticed that a defaultdict is generated only if `default is None`, as stated by the line below:

https://github.com/coin-or/pulp/blob/864bd98efdea5cc9bfc8d6b7300e319d2f174400/pulp/utilities.py#L159

I copied the `__makeDict()` and `makeDict()` definitions from the file and tested a little bit, noticing that the results were "switched" when compared with the current implementation (that I installed from conda), such that, when `default=None`, I was recieving a defaultdict, and when `default` was anything else, I was recieving the built-in dict type.

The statement should be `if not default is None`, right? Or am I missing something?

items.title: Goal Programming
items.body:
I'm using PuLP for a tank assignment problem.
This involves deciding on the number of tanks needed in a facility to make a number of campaigns of different products all at different cycle times.
The problem is quite complex, so I won't detail it all here.
Currently, I can optimize for a fairly straightforward objective: Minimize the cost of the installed tanks.
I'd like to do a goal programming approach, where I define a secondary objective (minimize the overall frequency of preparations, subject to fixing the cost of the installed tanks to the value obtained from solving the primary objective).
I can set the new objective function, and add a new constraint to fix the tank cost.

What I can't seem to figure out is how to use the values obtained in the primary solution as a first guess for the secondary problem, to cut down on solver time.
It would be great if there was a simple example of how to do such goal programming.
I saw some commits relating to "warm start" functionality, but I'm not sure how to implement it.
I'm using either the pulp-supplied CBC or standalone CBC to solve.

items.title: Contribution paperwork
items.body:
@stumitchell @pchtsp We have been lax in enforcing our IP and licensing requirements since moving to Github (which has been many years for PuLP). In SVN, we had pretty tight control over who could commit, but it is now possible to accept PRs from people who don't have write access. Just to remind you, our contribution guidelines are documented [here](https://www.coin-or.org/contributing/code/) and [here](https://projects.coin-or.org/CoinTLC/attachment/wiki/WikiStart/contribproc.pdf?format=raw) (the project management guidelines are a little out of date now, with the move to Github). 

The important part is that any significant/substantial contribution should be accompanied by a signed [Contributor's Statement of Respect for Ownership](https://www.coin-or.org/management/forms/csro.pdf). To make this process completely digital and to ease the burden of requesting contributors to sign such paperwork, we are planning to implement an automated system similar to that used by many bigger open source projects. Basically, anyone submitting a PR will automatically be asked to digitally sign a CSRO (this process will be quick and painless) if they haven't already done so). 

Given that PuLP is so active, I was hoping to use you as a beta test for the new system. The plan at the moment is to use the system developed by SAP and also used by Microsoft itself, as described here:

https://github.com/cla-assistant/cla-assistant 

If you agree, I will activate this for your project and we can see how it works. Ideally, I would also ask that you do your best to get your house in order regarding this paperwork. At the very least, the primary maintainers/developers should all have paperwork on file. Ideally, those who have contributed substantial chunks of code should be asked to sign retroactively (if anyone refuses, we will have to figure out what to do about that). 

Let me know what you think!

items.title: Pulp Model does not appear to respect variable lower bounds
items.body:
Details for the issue
--------------------

#### What did you do?
Transport problem with lower bounds set on all decision variables seem to have their lower bound constraints violated despite setting in the variable definition and/or as a manual constraint

#### What did you expect to see?
variables that are <0 == 0 

#### What did you see instead?
Negative values for variables with lower bounds set as 0.

Useful extra information
-------------------------

The info below often helps, please fill it out if you're able to. :)

#### What operating system are you using?

- [X] Windows: 10

#### I'm using python version:

- [X] 3.7.6

#### I installed PuLP via:

- [X] pypi (pip install pulp)

#### Did you also

- [ ] Tried out the latest github version: https://github.com/coin-or/pulp
- [X] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/coin-or/pulp/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20


Minimum Reprod. Example below:

```
import calendar
import datetime
import pandas as pd
import pulp as pulp

################################################################################
# DUMMY DATA

# Rail Capacity 
rail_capacity_df_daily = {'ABC': {'capacity_per_day': 3, 'total_allocated_capacity': 49},
                          'DEF': {'capacity_per_day': 1, 'total_allocated_capacity': 19},
                          'GHI': {'capacity_per_day': 1, 'total_allocated_capacity': 7},
}

rail_capacity_df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(rail_capacity_df_daily,orient='Index')

# Port Inventory
storage_stock_inventory = {
    'ZBF': {'current': 100000, 
            'target': 180000,
            'max': 200000}, 
    'AFM': {'current': 100000, 
            'target': 180000, 
            'max': 200000},
    'PRE': {'current': 100000, 
            'target': 180000, 
            'max': 200000},
    'AFE': {'current': 100000,
            'target': 180000,
            'max': 200000},
}

storage_inventory_df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(storage_stock_inventory, orient='Index')

# Production Plant Inventory
production_plant_inventory = {
    ('ABC', 'PRE'): {'inventory': 100000, 'daily_production': 3000},
    ('ABC', 'ZBF'): {'inventory': 100000, 'daily_production': 5000},
    ('DEF', 'AFM'): {'inventory': 100000, 'daily_production': 5000},
    ('DEF', 'PRE'): {'inventory': 100000, 'daily_production': 5000},
    ('GHI', 'AFE'): {'inventory': 100000, 'daily_production': 5000},
    ('GHI', 'PRE'): {'inventory': 100000, 'daily_production': 5000}
}  

production_plant_df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(
    production_plant_inventory,orient='Index').rename_axis(['plant', 'product'])

# Scenario: Over-demand
sales_demand = {
    '2020-05-18': {'AFM': 0, 'PRE': 0, 'ZBF': 0, 'AFE': 0},
    '2020-05-19': {'AFM': 200000, 'PRE': 200000, 'ZBF': 200000, 'AFE':200000},
    '2020-05-20': {'AFM': 200000, 'PRE': 200000, 'ZBF': 200000, 'AFE': 200000},
    '2020-05-21': {'AFM': 35000, 'PRE': 200000, 'ZBF': 200000, 'AFE': 200000},
    '2020-05-22': {'AFM': 200000, 'PRE': 200000, 'ZBF': 200000, 'AFE': 200000},
    '2020-05-23': {'AFM': 200000, 'PRE': 200000, 'ZBF': 200000, 'AFE': 200000},
}

# Sales Demand DF
sales_demand_df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(
    sales_demand, orient='Index').rename_axis(['date'])


###############################################################################
# DEFINE VARIABLES 

# FLAGS 
PLANNING_HORIZON_MAX = 5
CURRENT_DATE = datetime.date.today().strftime('%F')

# PLANNING HORIZON PARAMS  
_current_date = pd.to_datetime(datetime.datetime.today().strftime('%Y%m%d'))
planning_horizon_max = datetime.datetime.today() + datetime.timedelta(PLANNING_HORIZON_MAX)
planning_horizon_max = pd.to_datetime(planning_horizon_max.strftime('%Y%m%d'))

# COMBINATION VARS
dates = [d.strftime('%F') for d in pd.date_range(_current_date,planning_horizon_max)]
grades = [g for g in storage_inventory_df.index]

# production plants 
production_plants = ['ABC', 'DEF', 'GHI']

# production plants - no split trains
production_plant_no_split_trains = ['GHI']

# SALES DEMAND
# Demand: Current Sales Demand
sales_demand = sales_demand_df.to_dict(orient='index')

# Demand: Grade Combinations by Date
demand_requirements = [(d, g) for d in dates for g in grades]

# PRODUCTION VARS
# Production Plant Production & Inventory
production_plant_current_inventory = dict(zip(production_plant_df.index, 
                                              production_plant_df.inventory))
production_plant_daily_production = dict(zip(production_plant_df.index, 
                                             production_plant_df.daily_production))

production_plant_combinations = [
    (plant, grade) 
    for plant, grade in production_plant_df.index
]

# STORAGE INVENTORY VARS
# Storage Stockpile Initial Inventory
storage_stockpile_current = dict(zip(storage_inventory_df.index, 
                                     storage_inventory_df['current']))

# Storage Stockpile Target Inventory
storage_stockpile_target = dict(zip(storage_inventory_df.index, 
                                    storage_inventory_df['target']))

# Storage Stockpile Max Inventory Level
storage_stockpile_max = dict(zip(storage_inventory_df.index,
                                 storage_inventory_df['max']))

# RAIL_CAPACITY VARS
# Rail Capacity: No of Trains & Loading Constraints
total_trains_per_washplant = dict(zip(rail_capacity_df.index, 
                                      rail_capacity_df.capacity_per_day))

# Rail Capacity: No of trains per day limit
train_load_limit = dict(zip(rail_capacity_df.index,
                            rail_capacity_df.capacity_per_day))

max_no_trains = dict(zip(rail_capacity_df.index,
                         rail_capacity_df.total_allocated_capacity))

## DECISION_VARS
# Decision Vars, Trains: Date, Plant, Grade combos
train_consignment_variables = pulp.LpVariable.dicts(
    'Rail Loadings From Washplant',
    ((date, plant, grade) 
    for date in dates for (plant, grade) in production_plant_combinations),
    cat='Integer',
    lowBound=0) 

no_rail_splits_integer = pulp.LpVariable.dicts(
    'No Split Trains Integer', 
    ((date, plant, grade)
    for date in dates for plant, grade in production_plant_combinations 
    if plant in production_plant_no_split_trains),
    cat='Integer',
    lowBound=0)

# Decision Vars:  Production Plant inventory
production_plant_inventory_vars = pulp.LpVariable.dicts(
    'Production Plant Inventory',
    ((date, plant, grade) 
    for date in dates for (plant, grade) in production_plant_combinations),
    cat='Continuous',
    lowBound=0) 

# Decision Vars: Storage Inventory
storage_inventory_vars = pulp.LpVariable.dicts(
    'Port Inventory Levels',
    ((d, g) for d in dates for g in grades),
    cat='Continuous',
    lowBound=0)


# Pos difference variable between target and current inventory
storage_inventory_target_positive = pulp.LpVariable.dicts(
    'Storage Inventory Exceeds Target',
    ((d, g) for d in dates for g in grades),
    cat='Continuous',
    lowBound=0)

# Neg difference variable between target and current inventory
storage_inventory_target_negative = pulp.LpVariable.dicts(
    'Port Inventory Short Of Target',
    ((d, g) for d in dates for g in grades),
    cat='Continuous',
    lowBound=0)

# Insufficient Availabilty at Port
insufficient_storage_supply = pulp.LpVariable.dicts(
    'Insufficient Stock Availability',
    ((d, g) for d in dates for g in grades),
    cat='Continuous',
    lowBound=0)

# Binary variable that balances negative/positive inventory variations
binary = pulp.LpVariable.dicts(
    'Binary Indicator Insufficient Inventory',
    ((d, g) for d in dates for g in grades),
    cat='Binary')

###############################################################################

# DEFINE OPTIMISATION 
# Instantiate class
model = pulp.LpProblem('Rail Capacity Optimisation Test', pulp.LpMinimize)

solver = pulp.PULP_CBC_CMD()
solver.tmpDir = 'Users\CPrice2'

# Objective Function

model += pulp.lpSum(
    1000000 * storage_inventory_target_positive[(date, grade)]
    + 1000000 * storage_inventory_target_negative[(date, grade)]
    + 1000000 * insufficient_storage_supply[(date, grade)] 
    for date, grade in storage_inventory_vars
), 'Minimise stock shortfalls'

# Plant Inventory = Inv(t-1) + Prod(t) - demand(t)
for date in dates:
  current_date = CURRENT_DATE
  date_t_minus_one = datetime.datetime.strptime(date, '%Y-%m-%d') - \
      datetime.timedelta(days=1)
  date_t_minus_one = date_t_minus_one.strftime('%F')
  for plant, grade in production_plant_combinations:
    if date == current_date:
      # Set current inventory
      model += production_plant_current_inventory[(plant, grade)] \
          - train_consignment_variables[(date, plant, grade)] \
          + production_plant_daily_production[(plant, grade)] \
          == production_plant_inventory_vars[(date, plant, grade)]
    else:
      # Get inventory from t-1
      model += production_plant_daily_production[(plant, grade)] \
          + production_plant_inventory_vars[(f'{date_t_minus_one}', plant, grade)] \
          - train_consignment_variables[(date, plant, grade)] \
          == production_plant_inventory_vars[(date, plant, grade)]

# Plant Inventory > Min level
for date, plant, grade in production_plant_inventory_vars:
  plant_min_level = 5000
  plant_max_level = 200000
  model += production_plant_inventory_vars[(date, plant, grade)] \
      >= plant_min_level
  model += production_plant_inventory_vars[(date, plant, grade)] \
      <= plant_max_level

#Trains: Daily Rail Out Constraint For Split/Non-Split Rail
for date in dates:
  for plant in production_plants:
    plant_grade_combination = [
        tup for tup in production_plant_combinations 
        if tup[0] == plant
    ]
    variable_list = []
    for (plant_, grade_) in plant_grade_combination:
      variable = train_consignment_variables[(date, plant_, grade_)]
      variable_list.append(variable)
    model += pulp.lpSum(var for var in variable_list) \
        == train_load_limit[plant] * 8400
    for (plant_, grade_) in plant_grade_combination:
      if plant_ in production_plant_no_split_trains:
        model += train_consignment_variables[(date, plant_, grade_)] \
            == no_rail_splits_integer[(date, plant_, grade_)] * 8400 
      
# Total rail out must not exceed rail allocation per plant
for plant, grade in production_plant_combinations:
  all_shipments = []
  for date in dates:
    variable = train_consignment_variables[date, plant, grade]
    all_shipments.append(variable)
  model += 0 <= pulp.lpSum(var for var in all_shipments) \
      <= max_no_trains[plant] * 8400


# Stockpiles: Inventory = I(t-1) - d(t) + train_in(t) 
for date in dates:
  current_date = CURRENT_DATE
  date_t_minus_one = datetime.datetime.strptime(date, '%Y-%m-%d') \
      - datetime.timedelta(days=1)
  date_t_minus_one = date_t_minus_one.strftime('%F')
  for grade in grades:
    _plants_combo = [plant for plant in production_plants 
                     if (plant, grade) in production_plant_combinations]
    if date == current_date:
      # Current Inv == current inventory + train in
      model += storage_stockpile_current[grade] \
          + pulp.lpSum(
                train_consignment_variables[(date, plant, grade)] 
                for plant in _plants_combo) \
          - sales_demand[date][grade] \
          == storage_inventory_vars[(date, grade)]
    else:
      model += storage_inventory_vars[(f'{date_t_minus_one}', grade)] \
          - sales_demand[date][grade] \
          + pulp.lpSum(
                train_consignment_variables[(date, plant, grade)] 
                for plant in _plants_combo) \
          == storage_inventory_vars[(date, grade)]

# stockpile target, max/min and shortage constraints & sales demand
for date, grade in storage_inventory_vars:
  max_level = storage_stockpile_max[grade]
  target_level = storage_stockpile_target[grade]
  model += storage_inventory_vars[(date, grade)] <= max_level
  # Port Inventory Target Constraints
  model += storage_inventory_target_positive[(date, grade)] >= 0
  model += storage_inventory_target_positive[(date, grade)] - binary[(date, grade)] * 250000 <= 0
  model += storage_inventory_target_negative[(date, grade)] >= 0
  model += storage_inventory_target_negative[(date, grade)] - (1 - binary[(date, grade)]) * 250000 <= 0
  model += storage_inventory_vars[(date, grade)] >= target_level \
      - storage_inventory_target_negative[(date, grade)] \
      + storage_inventory_target_positive[(date, grade)]

# Sales Demand
# stockpile levels must meet sales demand
for date, grade in storage_inventory_vars:
  model += storage_inventory_vars[date, grade] \
      + insufficient_storage_supply[(date, grade)] \
      >= sales_demand[date][grade]
    
# Solve
model.solve(solver)
pulp.LpStatus[model.status]


# Get Variables 
stockpile_out = []

for (date, grade) in storage_inventory_vars:
  var_out = {
      'Date': date,
      'Grade': grade,
      'Sales Demand': sales_demand[date][grade],
      'Inventory Tonnes Out': storage_inventory_vars[(date, grade)].varValue,
      'Insufficient Tonnes': insufficient_storage_supply[(date, grade)].varValue
  }
  stockpile_out.append(var_out)

stockpile_out_df = pd.DataFrame.from_records(stockpile_out).sort_values(['Date', 'Grade'])
stockpile_out_df.set_index(['Date', 'Grade'], inplace=True)
stockpile_out_df.head(50)  
```

items.title: Feasible problem with Optimal solution has unsatisfied constrain
items.body:
Hi,

Relatively new to optimization. I am trying to solve a big knapsack with `PuLP`. After defining the model and running the program, the output seems reasonable and the status of the program is optimal yet my only constrain (the capacity of the knapsack) is not satisfied and the total weight of the items proposed by the solution is above the capacity of the knapsack. 

Since it is a knapsack with at least one item whose weight is smaller than the capacity, the problem is obviously feasible. I expected either an optimal solution that satisfies the constrain or a solution of a relaxed problem but then it is not optimal and the output of `.status` should not be `Optimal` if at least one constrain is not satisfied. 

I ran
```
import pulp as plp

prob = plp.LpProblem("Knapsack",plp.LpMaximize)

nb_item = ...
values = ...
weights = ...

X = [plp.LpVariable(str(n), 
                    lowBound = 0,
                    upBound = 1,
                    cat = plp.LpInteger) for n,i in enumerate(nb_item)]

prob += plp.lpSum([values[i]*X[i] for i in range(item_count)]), "Total value"
prob += plp.lpSum([weights[i]*X[i] for i in range(item_count)]) <= capacity, "Capacity of the bag constrain"

prob.solve()
```
and then, to get an idea of the output:
```
print("Status:", plp.LpStatus[prob.status])

if (prob.status == -1):
     print("Your problem is infeasible!")

sorted_var = sorted(prob.variables(), key=lambda x: int(x.name))
sorted_var_values = list([int(v.varValue) for v in sorted_var ])

print(f"Capacity constrain: {capacity}")
print(f"{sum([sorted_var_values[i]*weights[0][i] for i in range(item_count)])} of total value computed by hand")
print(f"{sum([sorted_var_values[i]*values[i] for i in range(item_count)])} of total weight computed by hand")

print(f"Total value = {int(plp.value(prob.objective))} computed by PuLP")
print(f"Is it valid : {prob.valid()}")

-----------------------
Status: Optimal
Capacity constrain: 9486367
9486400 of total value computed by hand
3967200 of total weight computed by hand
Total value = 3967200 computed by PuLP
Is it valid : False
```
We see that it is Optimal yet the constrain is not verified.
Is it normal ? Am I missing something ?
Can I force the constrain to satisfied ? 

Thanks a lot !

items.title: Fail to read a solution from GLPK where its status is integer empty
items.body:
Hello,

I found that pulp fails to read a .sol file from GLPK when the status in the .sol file is INTEGER EMPTY.  Here is the code that reproduces the error. [test.py.txt](https://github.com/coin-or/pulp/files/4569332/test.py.txt)

I think that the problem was that pulp did not treat the .sol file as a solution of MILP while actually it was MILP.  To fix the problem, I believe [isInteger](https://github.com/coin-or/pulp/blob/master/pulp/apis/glpk_api.py#L117) should be true when the status in the .sol file is INTEGER EMPTY.  That is, [the list](https://github.com/coin-or/pulp/blob/master/pulp/apis/glpk_api.py#L117)  should include "INTEGER EMPTY".  

Best,

items.title: Numpy-based array interface to pulp
items.body:
I would like to probe interest in the inclusion into mainline pulp of a **numpy-based array-oriented interface to collections of lp varibles and constraints**. Specifically, I've written a small helper library, [pulp-lparray](https://github.com/qdbp/pulp-lparray) to make working with arrays of LpVariables more intuitive, which I propose be included in pulp.

Pulp is very user-friendly, but I found its dict-based nature cumbersome and anti-idiomatic for working with multidimensional grids of variables. Numpy provides fantastic primitives for vectorized operations and implicit loops, and I wanted to leverage those to make my pulp code more terse and intuitive. An example of what my library looks like:

```
    sell_qty_limit = np.array([-t.qty for t in sells], dtype=np.uint32)
    buy_qty_limit = np.array([t.qty for t in buys], dtype=np.uint32)

    prob = LpProblem(sense=LpMinimize)
    match: lparray = lparray.create_anon("Match", (nb, ns), cat=LpInteger, lowBound=0)

    (match.sum(axis=0) <= sell_qty_limit).constrain(prob, "SellLimit")
    (match.sum(axis=1) <= buy_qty_limit).constrain(prob, "BuyLimit")

    cost = (match * loss).sumit()
    prob += cost
```

Another good example is the "SuperSudoku" on the readme page.

In addition to terser, less noisy syntax, `lparray` provides some backend-agnostic primitives such as min, max, abs, binarization, etc. These are less developed as I've added them mostly as the need comes up rather than in a systematic way.

I think that pulp will benefit from having an interface like this, but I don't want to send an unsolicited PR without consulting the community.

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

Created on Sat Apr  4 23:39:14 2020

import time

npdot_result=np.dot(consarray,var)

print("time for np.dot",t1-t)


t=time.time()
lpdot_result=lpDot(consarray,var)

#########changing the definition of original lpdot function ##############

t=time.time()
def isiterable(obj):
    try: obj=iter(obj)
    except: return False
    else: return True

#chaging original definition of lp by removing lpSum in last else condition
def lpDot(v1, v2):
    """Calculate the dot product of two lists of linear expressions"""
    if not isiterable(v1) and not isiterable(v2):
        return v1 * v2
    elif not isiterable(v1):
        return lpDot([v1]*len(v2),v2)
    elif not isiterable(v2):
        return lpDot(v1,[v2]*len(v1))
    else:
        return [lpDot(e1,e2) for e1,e2 in zip(v1,v2)]
```

items.body:
<!--
Thanks for coming here to report a bug. :)

Please describe it in the sections below, fill out the correct check boxes with an "x", replacing the space inside [ ], then click the "Submit new issue" button at the bottom
-->

Details for the issue
--------------------

#### What did you do?
1) Write a user-defined class which contains LpVariable fields.
2) Build instances of that class and save them to a local directory (many packages are appropriate for this, I used shelve).
3) Several days later (separate Python session etc.), I loaded the saved objects and attempted to instantiate lpSums, lpAffineExpressions and constraints between their fields.

For example, let myobj1 and myobj2 both contain LpVariable fields namely .num. The variables were instantiated with names that were different for each object.

obj1 = load_from_cache(myobj1)
obj2 = load_from_cache(myobj2)
my_objects = [obj1, obj2]
my_expr = lpSum([o.num for o in my_objects])    <- Interpreter never passes, this line, and instead gives "max recursion depth exceeded"

I notice myobj1.num == myobj2.num fails with the same error.

The hash of each variable, i.e. hash(myobj1.num) and hash(myobj2.num), are the same.

I expect the various LP functions to work as documented and not create 'recursion depth exceeded' errors, especially when the variables themselves have different names.

#### What did you see instead?
Pulp functions appear to call themselves recursively when hash of different variables are the same, leading to an error.

Hello,

So I am running my code across computers that may or may not have certain solvers installed.  I created a function to get "best available solver", i.e. this:

    def _get_best_solver():
        solvers = [
        pulp.GUROBI,
        pulp.GUROBI_CMD,
        #etc

        ]
        for solver in solvers:

                print(f"Solver {solver} is available")

        assert False, "No solver found"`

        solver = _get_best_solver()

I want to pass a time limit of (say) 300 seconds.  The problem is that the solver class initializers seem to have different methods of assigning a time limit. I'm not familiar with how to do pull requests, but I'd be willing to help make the changes

items.title: Model infeasible, but all constraints appear valid.
items.body:
Hi, first of all, I'm really enjoying using PuLP and finding it very useful, so thank you!

I'm looking to check which of my constraints are not being met by the returned solution to an infeasible problem (as a clue to which constraints I should relax).

I specify my model (called `model`) and constraints and then run the following:
```
solution_type = model.solve()

if solution_type == -1:
    warnings.warn('Problem infeasible.')
    for c_name in model.constraints:
        if not model.constraints[c_name].valid():
            print(c_name)
```
I get the 'Problem infeasible' warning, but none of my model constraints appears to be invalid, even ones that I can see are not satisfied by the current solution.

I'm wondering if I've misunderstood what .valid() is doing. Is there some other way of doing what I'm trying to do?

I'm using the pulp python package, version 1.6.10.

Thanks for your help!

items.title: Split out Amply into separate repository/Python package
items.body:
The functionality provided by Amply seems to be orthogonal to that of the PuLP. As far as I can tell, the Amply module is not directly called by any other part of the PuLP code base.

I therefore propose that Amply is split into a separate repository and becomes an independent Python package which can then be imported by PuLP (if it is required). 

Amply does have use - in fact I am making use of it in [otoole](http://github.com/OSeMOSYS/otoole) to read GLPK files (which are written in AMPL dialect).

Splitting out Amply into its own package would enable the further development of Amply to continue in parallel to that of PuLP, and allow more rapid deployment to PyPI etc.

items.title: Unexpected wrong solution on very simple problem
items.body:
Currently on the latest version installable from pip, using default solver.
With this simple problem, I'm getting an infeasible solution that for some reason is still considered optimal by the solver.

```
from pulp import LpProblem, LpMaximize, LpVariable, LpInteger, solvers, value
import math

prob = LpProblem("Pattern", LpMaximize)
max_l1 = math.floor(6000 / 392)
max_l2 = math.floor(6000 / 1347)
x1 = LpVariable("x1", 1, int(max_l1), LpInteger)
x2 = LpVariable("x2", 1, int(max_l2), LpInteger)
prob += 392 * x1 + 1347 * x2 <= 6000
prob += 392 * x1 + 1347 * x2
status = prob.solve()
diff = 6000 - (392 * value(x1) + 1347 * value(x2))
print(value(x1), value(x2), diff)
```

OUTPUT: 5.0 3.0 -1.0

The objective function results in the value 6001 even though the constraint specifies it has to be less than or equal to 6000.
This is the only weird result, after processing about 30000 similar problems.

As far as I can see, it looks like a sort of rounding error on the x1 variable, but I'm not expecting something like that in a problem so simple.

**EDIT:
Updating cbc.exe to latest version solved the issue. 
It would be nice if the latest version of the solver were added to the next release. I see many issues on here that are probably connected to that.**

items.title: CPLEX and Spaces in File Names
items.body:
If you name your MIP something like 
`problem = LpProblem("A Name With Spaces", LpMaximize)`

and then go to solve it with CPLEX like
`problem.solve(solver=pulp.CPLEX_CMD(msg=0, options=[f'set mip tolerances mipgap 0'], keepFiles = 1))`

the LP will come back with infeasible status. 

Digging into the log, you'll find
```
CPLEX Error  1423: Could not open file 'A' for reading.
CPLEX Error  1423: Could not open file 'A.prm' for reading.
No file read.
New value for mixed integer optimality gap tolerance: 0
No problem exists.
```
where CPLEX seems to only be looking for the text before the first space.

A warning or error here would be great for users trying to combine CPLEX and problem names with spaces.

items.title: Feature request - handling multidimensional decision variables
items.body:
I was looking for a scaleable way to handle multidimensional decision variables and came up with the following.
Would something like this be suitable for inclusion to PuLP?
It does require numpy (but any large multidimensional array problem in python is probably using numpy already). Perhaps it's possible to specify numpy as an optional dependency?
I'm very much an amateur, hence this not being a proper pull request!

```
import numpy
import pulp


class LpVariableArray:
    """Multidimensional decision variable array."""

    def __init__(
        self, name, dimensions, low_bound=None, up_bound=None, cat=None, e=None
    ):
        self.name = name
        try:
            iter(dimensions)
            self.dimensions = dimensions
        except TypeError:
            self.dimensions = (dimensions,)
        self.low_bound = low_bound
        self.up_bound = up_bound
        self.cat = cat
        self.e = e
        self.variables = self._build_variables_array()
        self.values = None

    def __getitem__(self, index):
        return self.variables[index]

    def _define_variable(self, *index):
        """Defines an individual decision variable."""
        name = "_".join(map(str, (self.name, *index)))
        return pulp.LpVariable(
            name, self.low_bound, self.up_bound, self.cat, self.e
        )

    def _build_variables_array(self):
        """Builds a multidimensional array of decision variables."""
        vfunc = numpy.vectorize(self._define_variable)
        return numpy.fromfunction(vfunc, self.dimensions, dtype="int")

    def evaluate(self):
        """Evaluates decision variable values."""
        vfunc = numpy.vectorize(lambda i: pulp.value(i))
        self.values = vfunc(self.variables)
```

Variables can be defined as e.g.
```
x = LpVariableArray("x", (1,2,3), 4.56, 7.89, "Continuous")
y = LpVariableArray("y", 100, 1, 10, "Integer") 
z = LpVariableArray("z", (10,10), "Binary") 
```
Multidimensional constraints can be defined e.g.:
```
for n in range(N):
            problem += sum([x[n, p] for p in range(P)]) == 1
```
Once a problem has been solved, values can be calculated as follows:
```
x.evaluate()
```
...and returned as
```
x.values
```
or, e.g.:
```
x.values[1,1,1]
```

items.title: Assertion error with CBC when run through pulp
items.body:
I'm getting the following error when I use my system CBC (coin-or-cbc 2.10.1-1 on Arch Linux x86-64) via PuLP on a particular problem:
``cbc: CglProbing.cpp:614: int CglProbing::tighten(double*, double*, const int*, const double*, const CoinBigIndex*, const CoinBigIndex*, const int*, double*, double*, int, int, char*, int, double): Assertion `colUpper[j]==colLower[j]' failed.``
The problem solves fine using the version of CBC bundled with PuLP (i.e. `pulp.solvers.PULP_CBC_CMD`) but it also solves fine if I output an .lp file using `writeLP` and run the following from the command line:
`cbc myproblem.lp` 
I initially thought it was a bug in CGL (coin-or-cgl 0.60.1-1 on Arch Linux x86-64) or CBC, but since CBC can solve the problem from the command line, I think it might be an issue with PuLP.
The assertion test that's failing was added in a (relatively) recent commit to CGL; [cce4bed](https://github.com/coin-or/Cgl/commit/cce4bed8efa3ab5d2bc2999208bea145f909c75d).

The .lp file is attached below (github is forcing me to rename it *.txt) and it should solve relatively quickly (about 30 seconds on my laptop (Xeon E-2186M, 32GB RAM)).

items.body: *content*: Situation, Traceback/output, Math Formulation, Descriptive Formulation, Code, Software ---------------------- **Situation** - I am building and solving large optimal facility location models with restricted-use census microdata as part of my dissertation. The biggest troublemaker model is the p-center problem (a.k.a. minimax location-allocation; a mixed integer programming model for location-allocation) – [formulation, description, and code sample below]. I am working in a [restricted data center environment](https://www.census.gov/fsrdc) on a large cluster where memory is not an issue (100s of GB of RAM are readily available). - The error message is general and does not provide information on what actually broke. My first thought was that the problem is too large/difficult to solve (which I hope I am wrong…). I have not been able to reproduce the error, and even getting the traceback approved for disclosure took some finagling - Problem size - (10,000-row; 15-column) cost matrix - 170,001 constraints - 150,016 variables - unclear error message - P=1 (choose 1 candidate facility to minimize the maximum cost) solves in roughly 45 minutes with a minimal memory footprint - P=2 (choose 2 candidate facilities) errors out - Still trying to work down from p=15 - Will be trying to solve a much larger problem… - (~95,000-row; 15-column) cost matrix - 1,615,001 constraints - 1,425,016 variables - This model is known for being difficult to solve and unpredictable, but generally is more difficult to solve as p decreases from the maximum possible value, but is not 1. -------------------------- Formulation** -------------------------- **Code (boiled-down sample in a class)** ```python import pulp import numpy as np class FacilityLocationModel: """Solve a facility locatiom optimization model Parameters ---------- name : str Problem model name; must also be defined as a class method. cij : numpy.ndarray cost matrix from origins (index of i) to destination (index of j). Default is None. p : int Density of facilities to site. Default is None. Methods ------- build_pcp : build p-center problem problem_instance : create a problem instance add_vars : add variables to a model add_constrs : add contraints to a model add_obj : add an objective function to a model optimize : solve a model Attributes ---------- problem : pulp.pulp.LpProblem problem/model instance n_cli : int total client sites r_cli : range iterable of client sites n_fac : int total candidate facility sites r_fac : range iterable of candidate facility sites cli_decisions : list, np.array client-to-service decision variable matrix used in pmp and pcp. fac_vars : dict facility decision variables cli_vars : dict client decision variables W : pulp.pulp.LpVariable minimized maximum variable in the p-center problem formulation """ def __init__(self, name, cij=None, p=None, cli_dvs=None, fac_dvs=None): # Set model information self.name = name # Set parameters and indices # facility parameter self.p = p # client count and range self.cij = cij self.n_cli = cij.shape[0] self.r_cli = range(self.n_cli) # facility count and range self.n_fac = self.cij.shape[1] self.r_fac = range(self.n_fac) # if client and service decision variable names are passed in the # class, set them as attributes here. if fac_dvs is not None: self.fac_dvs = list(fac_dvs) if cli_dvs is not None: self.cli_dvs = list(cli_dvs) # Set decision variables, constraints, and objective function try: getattr(self, 'build_'+self.name)() except: raise AttributeError(self.name, 'not a defined location model.') # solve self.optimize() def build_pcp(self): """Integer programming formulation of the p-center Problem. Originally Published: S. L. Hakimi. 1964. Optimum Locations of Switching Centers and the Absolute Centers and Medians of a Graph. Operations Research. 12 (3):450-459. Adapted from: Daskin, M. (1995). Network and discrete location: Models, algorithms, and applications. New York: John Wiley and Sons, Inc. """ # Problem Instance self.problem_instance() # Decision Variables self.add_vars() # Constraints self.add_constrs(constr=2) # assignment constraints self.add_constrs(constr=3) # facility constraint self.add_constrs(constr=4) # opening constraints self.add_constrs(constr=5) # minimized maximum constraints # Objective Function self.add_obj() def problem_instance(self): """Create a problem instance and set objective sense. """ # set sense sense = pulp.LpMinimize # create problem instance self.problem = pulp.LpProblem(self.name, sense) def add_vars(self): """Add variables to a model. """ # facility decision variables # variable names if not hasattr(self, 'fac_dvs'): self.fac_dvs = ['y%i' % j for j in self.r_fac] # pulp.LpVariable objects self.fac_vars = [pulp.LpVariable(var_name, cat='Binary')\ for var_name in self.fac_dvs] # add variables self.problem.addVariables(v for v in self.fac_vars) # client decision variables # variable names if not hasattr(self, 'cli_dvs'): self.cli_dvs = ['x%i' % i for i in self.r_cli] self.cli_decisions = [['x%i_%i' % (i,j) for j in self.r_fac]\ for i in self.r_cli]\ # pulp.LpVariable objects self.cli_vars = [[pulp.LpVariable(var_name, cat='Binary')\ for var_name in var_row]\ for var_row in self.cli_decisions] # add variables self.problem.addVariables(var for var_row in self.cli_vars\ for var in var_row) # minimized maximum variable self.W = pulp.LpVariable('W', cat='Continuous') self.problem.addVariable(self.W) def add_constrs(self, constr=None): """ Add constraints to a model. (2) assignment constraints x1_1 + x1_2 + x1_3 = 1 (3) facility constraints y1 + y2 + y3 = p (4) opening constraints - x1_1 + y1 >= 0 - x2_1 + y1 >= 0 - x3_1 + y1 >= 0 (5) minimax constraints cost1_1*x1_1 + cost1_2*x1_2 + cost1_3*x1_3 - W <= 0 Parameters ---------- constr : int {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} Contraint type to add to model. See above for explanation. Default is None. """ # 2 - assignment constraints if constr == 2: constrs = [pulp.lpSum(self.cli_vars[i][j] for j in self.r_fac) == 1\ for i in self.r_cli] # 3 - facility constraint elif constr == 3: constrs = [pulp.lpSum(self.fac_vars[j]\ for j in self.r_fac) == self.p] # 4 - opening constraints elif constr == 4: constrs = [self.fac_vars[j] >= self.cli_vars[i][j]\ for i in self.r_cli for j in self.r_fac] # 5 - minimax constraints elif constr == 5: constrs = [pulp.lpSum(self.cij[i,j]\ * self.cli_vars[i][j] for j in self.r_fac) <= self.W\ for i in self.r_cli] # Add constraints [self.problem.addConstraint(c) for c in constrs] def add_obj(self): """ Add an objective function to a model. """ self.problem.setObjective(self.W) def optimize(self, write_lp=None): """ Solve the model. """ self.problem.solve(pulp.PULP_CBC_CMD(fracGap=0)) if __name__ == '__main__': np.random.seed(0) clients, facilities = 5, 3 p = 2 # 5 by 3 matrix of small integers cost_matrix = np.random.randint(1,5, size=(clients,facilities)) pcp = FacilityLocationModel('pcp', cij=cost_matrix, p=p) obj = pcp.problem.objective.value() print('Worst-case travel cost while siting %s facilities: %s' % (p, obj)) ``` ``` Worst-case travel cost while siting 2 facilities: 3.0 ``` -------------------------- **Software** - Python 3.6.3 - Pulp 1.6.8 - Numpy 1.15.1 - Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6.10 on PBS Pro cluster

items.title: Implementing Constraints for the Unit Commitment
items.body:
Consider the Unit Commitment problem with decision variables for each hour as 0/1 using MIP = 1. Meaning that for gen_commited[t] = 1 the generating unit will be on for the given point in time of the optimization.

A general constraint for the unit commitment problem is the minimum up/down time which determines that a generating unit must be on of off for a minimum time. I am working on just getting two hours tied to each other using PuLP as the following:

_The general formulation:_
gen_committed [t+1] >= gen_committed [t] - gen_committed [t-1] meaning that if the hour [t] is committed, the hour [t+1] must also be committed, this extends to further hours.

_PuLP implementation:_
for t in time:
       gen_committed[min(t+1,h-1)] >= gen_committed[t] - gen_committed[t-1]

The min() is used in order to limit the list to the given timespan (h-1), where time = h

The constraint ain't doing its job and simply wont work as i want it to. Further, the "PULP_CBC_CMD"  does return strange statuses for this implementation, sometimes infeasible, sometimes optimal. 


Can anyone help me with where i go wrong?

items.title: misleading solving status returned in COIN_CMD, GUROBI_CMD and CPLEX_CMD
items.body:
Following [this](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/pulp-or-discuss/hP0eqjyYEDM) google group's entry, I'm creating an issue to remind me to do something about it.

I describe the problem here:

In the case of GUROBI and CPLEX solvers (at least in the `CMD` interface), pulp returns 1 ('optimal') when an integer solution has been found in the time limit.

This is not the behavior I get from the CBC solver, which returns 0.

Since having found an integer solution when the time stops is neither "optimal" nor "not solved", both are at the same time misleading and inconsistent.

One possibility is to at least make all solvers return the same status when finishing in the same status. This would make CBC return 1 instead of 0 when at least one integer solution was found. This is easy to change.

The second, more ambitious possibility, would be to create a new "Integer solution" status in pulp that differentiates from "optimal" and "no solution". This would then be used in the solver interfaces as an additional status to return.

I'll check how the second one could be done.

In case it's hard to implement, would the first one be an acceptable change?

regards,

Franco

items.title: Constraints only considered when there's an equal to symbol included
items.body:
Consider "x" an integer ranging between 0 to 10.
Objective is: x + 10
Problem is: Minimize
Constraint: x > 4.1
Expected Result: x = 5, obj = 15
Obtained Result: x = 0, obj = 10
Code:
```python
from pulp import *
prob = LpProblem("test1", LpMinimize)
x = LpVariable("x", 0, 10, 'Integer')
prob += x + 10, "obj"
prob += x > 4.1, "c1"
prob.solve()
print("Status:", LpStatus[prob.status])
print(prob.variables()[0].name, "=", prob.variables()[0].varValue)
print("objective=", value(prob.objective))
```
I've observed that by changing the constraint from ">" to ">=" and it worked as expected.

Code:
```python
from pulp import *
prob = LpProblem("test1", LpMinimize)
x = LpVariable("x", 0, 10, 'Integer')
prob += x + 10, "obj"
prob += x >= 4.1, "c1"   #Changed the constraint from > to >=
prob.solve()
print("Status:", LpStatus[prob.status])
print(prob.variables()[0].name, "=", prob.variables()[0].varValue)
print("objective=", value(prob.objective))
```
Obtained Result: x = 5, obj = 15

items.title: Pulp ignores constraints if infeasible
items.body:
### Issue

Pulp will ignore certain constraints if a problem is deemed infeasible without notifying the user.

### Examples

For example, to ignore LpInteger, consider solving:
```
4x + 2y = 3
2x + 4y = 3
```
If this is entered into pulp (code attached) where each variable is constructed via `LpVariable('x',0,1,LpInteger)` , pulp spits back that `x` and `y` are both `0.5`, despite being explicitly told to solve only for integers.

Another example is ignoring upper and lower bounds
```
4x + 2y = 30
2x + 4y = 30
```
Here pulp returns `x` and `y` equal `5.0`. Again, variables are constructed via `LpVariable('x',0,1,LpInteger)`, yet the upper bound of 1 is ignored.

### Code

[break_pulp.py.zip](https://github.com/coin-or/pulp/files/1473304/break_pulp.py.zip)

items.title: solvers.py: solve_CBC() crashes when white space in path name
items.body:
Line 1419 of solvers.py contains the following expression:
`cbc = subprocess.Popen((self.path + cmds).split(), stdout = pipe,
                             stderr = pipe)`

This code will crash if self.path contains a white space character. Normally, this should not be the case but it can happen. One example is the usage of py2app or py2exe, which bundles pulp. Moving the .app or .exe to a directory with a white space in the path, will crash the app.

items.title: value() or .value()?
items.body:
https://pythonhosted.org/PuLP/CaseStudies/a_set_partitioning_problem.html has

~~~
#create a binary variable to state that a table setting is used
x = pulp.LpVariable.dicts('table', possible_tables, 
                            lowBound = 0,
                            upBound = 1,
                            cat = pulp.LpInteger)

...

print("The choosen tables are out of a total of %s:"%len(possible_tables))
for table in possible_tables:
    if x[table].value() == 1.0:
        print(table)
~~~

but https://pythonhosted.org/PuLP/pulp.html says that the correct would be

~~~
for table in possible_tables:
    if value(x[table]) == 1.0:
        print(table)
~~~

items.title: SafeConfigParser deprecated in favor of ConfigParser
items.body:
I get the following deprecation warning when I load PuLP.

```
(venv) ~ $ python -Wd
Python 3.6.2 (default, Jul 17 2017, 16:44:45) 
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Apple LLVM 8.1.0 (clang-802.0.42)] on darwin...
>>> import pulp
/.../venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pulp/solvers.py:71: DeprecationWarning: The SafeConfigParser class has been renamed to ConfigParser in Python 3.2. This alias will be removed in future versions. Use ConfigParser directly instead.
  'os':operating_system, 'arch':arch})
```

Maybe related to #124, but probably not.

## Proposed fix

Replace `configparser.SafeConfigParser` in [solvers.py](https://github.com/coin-or/pulp/blob/master/src/pulp/solvers.py#L70) with `configparser.ConfigParser`. My understanding is that the API is the same.

items.title: Support Vector Machine with Pulp
items.body:
Hi,
I'm trying to compare SVM solve with Pulp vs Scikit-learn using the following LP problem:
![equation](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30179790/28216933-49697dc8-68ab-11e7-8365-ae55e1118a51.jpg)
Unfortunately, Pulp return some value for **b** and **Eta**, but **Alpha** and **a** are stuck to zero.
I'm question the way I implemented it as I can't find the constrains with the Kernel matrix in the LP file...  

# SVM implementation in Pulp vs Scikit-learn

    import numpy as np
    import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
    from sklearn.svm import SVR
    from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import rbf_kernel
    from pulp import *
    
    def CompPulpSlk():

    N = 100
    x = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, N)
    y = np.sin(x) + np.random.random(N) * 1
    x.resize(N, 1)
    K = rbf_kernel(x, gamma=5)

    # define de problem for Pulp

    # define the hyper parameters
    C = 10
    eps = 0.1

    # define the variables
    RANGE = list(range(N))
    alpha = pulp.LpVariable.dicts("alpha", (RANGE,), cat='Continuous')
    b = pulp.LpVariable("b", cat='Continuous')
    a = pulp.LpVariable.dicts("a", (RANGE,), lowBound=0, cat='Continuous')
    Eta = pulp.LpVariable.dicts("Eta", (RANGE,), lowBound=0, cat='Continuous')

    prob = LpProblem("Constrained SVM", LpMinimize)

    # implementing the constrains to Pulp
    for i in range(N):
        prob += lpDot(alpha, K[i]) + b - y[i] >= -Eta[i]
        prob += lpDot(alpha, K[i]) + b - y[i] <= Eta[i]
        prob += eps >= 0
        prob += eps <= Eta[i]
        prob += alpha[i] <= a[i]
        prob += alpha[i] >= -a[i]

    # call the objective function
    prob += lpSum(a) + C * lpSum(Eta)

    prob.writeLP("MySVM.lp")
    prob.solve()

    print("Status:", LpStatus[prob.status])

    #storing Optimisation result
    varDic = {}
    for v in prob.variables():
        if v.name[:5] == 'alpha' or v.name == 'b':
            varDic[v.name] = v.varValue

    #passing solution (alpha, beta) to proper ndarray
    b = varDic['b']
    del varDic['b']

    alp = np.zeros(N)
    for key in varDic:
        alp[int(key[6:])] = varDic[key]


    #clean up PULP variables
    alpha.clear()
    Eta.clear()
    a.clear()
    varDic.clear()

    #Projection of the solution from Pulp and Sci-learn
    y_pulp = np.zeros(N)
    for i in range(N):
        y_pulp[i] = np.dot(alp, K[i, :]) + b

    svr_rbf = SVR(kernel='rbf', C=1e3, gamma=0.1)
    y_rbf = svr_rbf.fit(x, y).predict(x)

    #display result
    lw = 2
    plt.scatter(x, y, color='darkorange', label='data')
    plt.hold('on')
    plt.plot(x, y_rbf, color='navy', lw=lw, label='SciLearn')
    plt.plot(x, y_pulp, color='cornflowerblue', lw=lw, label='Pulp')
    plt.xlabel('data')
    plt.ylabel('target')
    plt.title('Support Vector Regression')
    plt.legend()
    plt.show()
